content.title: Botanica Lab, the renewal of vegetarian cuisine

introduction.small: In Bologna, Botanica Lab gives vegetarian cuisine a good name. Quality, innovation and complementary flavours.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Botanica Lab, the renewal of vegetarian cuisine

paragraphs.text:
The child project of Anne Artesiani, who studied with the greatest chefs in the field of vegetarian cuisine, Botanica Lab Cucina will please even fervent carnivores. The staff will go beyond to sweep away any doubt you may have: this creative, eclectic and organic cuisine is prepared using seasonal, gluten-free ingredients. Another driving force is to serve raw food, hence preserving flavours and nutritional values. From classic buddha bowls, sandwiches and pizzas (whole pies or slices) to more adventurous tempeh (soybean-based paste) served with Jerusalem artichoke cream and grilled nuts, or a delicious avocado-chocolate cream, everything is homemade. A lovely and affordable wine selection completes the experience.

Alternately, head to Botanica Lab Café for its arabica, tea, flavourful cakes and brioches. A gourmet break indeed!

Botanica Lab
Via Battibecco, 4
40123 Bologna

+39 342 860 6026

https://www.botanicalab.com/?lang=en

Menu: from 18 EUR

content.title: Mozzabella, true Bologna pizza

introduction.small: After Roman and Neapolitan pizzas, welcome the Bologna counterpart! Mozzabella creates original associations and toppings.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Mozzabella, true Bologna pizza

paragraphs.text:
On Pratello Street in Bologna, the small red sign attracts an eclectic clientele, with one common point: they all love pizza. Mozzabella is the first Bolognese pizza brand, drawing inspiration from Neapolitan margherita but changing the dough being used (with a choice of whole wheat, einkorn wheat etc…) and offering a rectangular version of the Italian classic. The young and creative staff values Italian skills and products, using suppliers from the Emilia-Romagna region. In the entrance, the various ingredients - all organic - being used are displayed on shelves, meaning that if you've had a crush on that burrata, you will be able to buy some at the restaurant's deli corner. On the menu, a dozen seasonal offerings take centre stage, sometimes with unexpected toppings, like this pumpkin-gorgonzola mix. Also serving slices, Mozzabella is a perfect spot for a snack, or if you feel like trying multiple recipes at once!

Mozzabella

40122 Bologna

+39 051 550 506

https://www.facebook.com/mozzabellapizzeria/

Menu: pizza from 10 EUR

content.title: Sophisticated cocktails at Casa Minghetti

introduction.small: Mixology as an art of its own at Casa Minghetti, trendy cocktail bar in Bologna.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Sophisticated cocktails at Casa Minghetti

paragraphs.text:
Casa Minghetti took up residence on Minghetti Piazza, one of Bologna's most beautiful squares. Favoured by cocktail lovers, the bar is always crowded as soon as the night sets in. Candles burn and light up the patio through lanterns made of zinc. Inside, the small drinking room subtly blends a vintage look enhanced by a painted ceiling, with modern decoration. However, everything truly happens at the counter, where house mixologist Pano works his magic. Order – in moderation – one of his signature drinks, like the Dolce Vita (whisky, cedar juice, almond and Morello cherry syrups, soda water) or the Californication (gin, cranberry liquor, melon juice, jalapeño and Mexican bitter), and pay attention to the artistry in the making. If you're lucky, you may even witness one of these bartender contests and take advantage to try new recipes.

Casa Minghetti

https://www.facebook.com/casaminghettibologna/

content.title: The Asinelli tower, the highest in Bologna

introduction.small: Climb up to the top of the highest tower in Bologna, a sporty stroll gratifying you with a spectacular view over the city.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Asinelli tower, the highest in Bologna

paragraphs.text:
Bologna is well-known for its towers, counting more than 100 from the 11th to the 13th centuries. Today, just about twenty of these medieval structures have survived time and natural disasters. The 320-feet high Asinelli tower (Torre degli Asinelli) is the city's highest building, with the peculiarity of being slightly at an angle. For three euros, you can go up the 498 steps – occasional athletes take note! – to the summit for a real hike in the heart of the city. Once at the top you can look out over the famous red roofs of the city of Bologna.
The Asinelli tower was built between 1109 and 1119 by the family of the same name. Other than its military purpose, the towers symbolised the social prestige of their owners. At the time, competition between families raged to see who was the wealthiest and most powerful.

content.title: Vestiges of the past at the I Portici Hotel

introduction.small: In the heart of Bologna, get ready to travel through Italian history, from Ancient Rome to the Renaissance.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Vestiges of the past at the I Portici Hotel

paragraphs.text:
Located in downtown Bologna, the I Portici Hotel houses the vestiges of a former theatre and a stunning antique underground wine cellar. At its creation, the theatre served as a café-concert named "Eden Kursaal" in the 19th and 20th centuries. Awarded a Michelin star in 2012, the restaurant serves refined Italian dishes in an original decor with frescoes from the Belle Époque. The secret underground wine cellar was part of the fortress of Galliera, also known as "Castle of the Popes". While the castle was destroyed several times, the cellar always remained intact. It is there that you can enjoy a romantic tête-à-tête with candlelit dinner in a subdued atmosphere. After your meal, you will go up to one of the 100 rooms decorated by Italian and international designers. Finally, what better way to end the end than by admiring the sunset from the terrace over the Parco della Montagnola?

I Portici Hotel Bologna

content.title: Ferrare, gem of the Po Valley

introduction.small: Next stop is Ferrare and its fortifications, a city that always favoured art and is now designated a UNESCO World Heritage Site. The greatest Italian artists from the Renaissance sung its praises.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Ferrare, gem of the Po Valley

paragraphs.text:
It takes about an hour from Bologna to reach Ferrare. In the early Renaissance period when powerful families of the Italian aristocracy came along, the small village transformed into a large artistic avant-garde city, right until the 16th century. This is where Ariosto wrote his epic masterpiece, Orlando Furioso, inspired by Middle-Aged Songs of Deeds.

Just like the poet, various painters, thinkers and engravers had found themselves at the Duke's court. This cultural turmoil slowed down a little before major rebirth in the early 20th century, when Giorgio De Chirico especially decided to settle and paint some of his most beautiful work there.

Ferrare is best discovered on a bike to enjoy the mild Italian climate. The old medieval city, its fortifications including the Este Castle, as well as unique architecture and urban plans, are testimonies of a golden age when it was on par with Venice and Florence.

Este Castle

content.title: Have a drink and a bite at Stanze

introduction.small: Bolognese students gather in this sublime setting in time for aperitivo. Discover this extraordinary place!

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Have a drink and a bite at Stanze

paragraphs.text:
Right in the middle of the student neighbourhood, Stanze is located in the old Bentivoglio family chapel that was built in the 16th century. On the walls and ceilings, you can admire beautiful period frescoes displaying religious and mythological scenes. The owners took the opportunity to add elements of vintage and contemporary decoration for a truly stunning result.

At the bar, ask for cocktails, from spritz to mojitos, unless you prefer a glass of wine or a soft drink. As aperitivo tradition would have it, order a drink and for a few euros more enjoy all-you-can-eat tapas. And if you are still hungry, do not hesitate, draw the night out and have dinner on the spot. You can help yourself to the buffet or enjoy traditional dishes made of regional products, like Parma ham, pasta, grilled vegetables and delicious mixed salads.

content.title: Lazing about in Rimini

introduction.small: By train from Bologna, you can reach the sea in an hour. Rimini's beaches will warm your soul and so will the city beyond.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Lazing about in Rimini

paragraphs.text:
On the Adriatic shore, Rimini's fine sand beaches spread over 25 km. As time went by, the birthplace of filmmaker Federico Fellini changed a lot. Travellers come from all Europe to enjoy the regional climate and its seaside luxury hotels, as Rimini maintains its reputation as a warm, welcoming and festive city.

You will never be alone on the beach. Each stretch develops its own style, and whether club or family oriented, there will be something for you.

Behind the deckchairs and ice-cream dealers, the inner city reveals itself to be particularly authentic, as inhabitants managed to preserve the soul of the area. As an old Roman port, Rimini is full of historical monuments that bear witness to the glory of the ancient Empire. Do not miss the Bridge of Tiberus, the Arch of Augustus, the Roman Amphitheatre as well as the later Middle-Aged or Renaissance gems.

content.title: La Grassa, because it tastes so good

introduction.small: Capital of gastronomy, sharing and friendliness, Bologna is well worth a visit for its food markets and treats.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: La Grassa, because it tastes so good

paragraphs.text:
Bologna's charm can be found in its gastronomy, food specialities and small markets, where it is possible to feel this particular Mediterranean atmosphere, at once welcoming, outgoing and full of life. At each street corner in the Quadrilatero, you will pass delicatessens and butcher shops, bakeries and traditional little restaurants in which it is mandatory to try Bolognese specialities like mortadella and tortellini. But that's not all! The oldest trade district in town also offers Parma ham and parmesan products, very easy to come by: you simply have to stop in every alleyway at a food stand and play the game of bargaining for the best price!

Another prerequisite while in Bologna are the treats merchants. The old capital of Emilia-Romagna shelters many ice-cream makers and bakeries, like La Sorbetteria Castiglione, one of the most representative ice-cream shops in the city. Under the archways, do not miss Gamberini, the oldest bakery in Bologna, famous for its cakes, coffee and aperitivo.

content.title: Gelati at Stefino

introduction.small: Where to eat the best ice cream in Bologna? Here is a question too difficult to answer. However, the irreplaceable Stefino Gelateria remains the trendiest.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Gelati at Stefino

paragraphs.text:
Set amidst the student neighbourhood, only a few metres away from the university, Gelateria Stefino receives unanimous support, especially from the Bolognese youth.

It must be said that Stefino is without a doubt the most innovative regarding ethics and fair trade. Ice creams are certified "organic". Of course, they are homemade, and the products used in their composition all come from local producers. At Stefino, if some ice creams are vegan or gluten-free, the others are exclusively made of unpasteurised milk. Whatever the ingredients, they all are light, with low sugar and fat levels.

Whether they are ice creams or sorbets, available flavours are simple and adequate: Bourbon vanilla, Sicilian pistachio, chocolate, nougat, peach-orange blossom, lemon-basil and bergamot-orange...

Under the archways with an ice cream in hand ready for consumption, your day in Bologna will feel a little closer to heaven.

content.title: Grand Hotel Majestic Già Baglioni, Italian saga

introduction.small: Without a doubt the place to be, the mythical Grand Hotel Majestic stands tall at the very heart of Bologna's historical centre.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Grand Hotel Majestic Già Baglioni, Italian saga

paragraphs.text:
Sumptuous is the word that springs to mind once you cross the hotel threshold. Located in an 18th-century building, the Grand Hotel Majestic is on par with Bologna's greatest palaces. Gold decorations, marble, period frescoes and mouldings consecrate the venetian style, slightly lifted with modernist touches.

The only five-star-hotel in Bologna cultivates a unique expertise in the field of hotel trade. The staff is discreet and attentive. There are 109 rooms in the hotel, seven meeting rooms all fully equipped, as well as a typically Italian café and a restaurant, I Carricci, named after the famous brothers, both born in Bologna.
Exquisite regional and national dishes are served and a large selection of wine is available. The cherry on top: just look up at the restaurant's ceiling and wonder at a remarkable fresco.

content.title: MAMbo: Italian Contemporary Art to the forefront

introduction.small: Spread over three floors, the Museo d'Arte Moderna di Bologna (MAMbo) owes its reputation to a wonderful collection of notorious artists and to its role of talent scout.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: MAMbo: Italian Contemporary Art to the forefront

paragraphs.text:
The city of Bologna loves to create Museums and art centres in historical places. The MAMbo itself is located in a former forno del pane (bread oven) that was transformed over the years as a storage warehouse and then as a museum. The renovation project has been handed to the Milan-based Arassociati architecture agency.

The MAMbo permanent collection is mainly comprised of Italian works of art from WW2 up to now. You can admire the work of Paolo Manaresi, or the still lives of Giorgio Morandi, a painter from Bologna who was awarded the first prize for painting at the 1948 Venice Biennale.

Besides the permanent collection, MAMbo offers a very eclectic program of temporary exhibitions, from the Oreste collective of designers or sarcastic plastician Mika Rottenberg to visual artist Cesare Pietroiusti. And when the must-see David Bowie Is exhibition toured the world, it stopped at MAMbo.

MAMbo

content.title: Savoy Hotel, for a break in Parma

introduction.small: A small and modern hotel midst the centre of Parma, the Savoy Hotel is an ideal pied-à-terre to discover the charms of the old town.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Savoy Hotel, for a break in Parma

paragraphs.text:
Completely redesigned by the architecture agency Solenghi & Scognamiglio, the Savoy Hotel displays a contemporary style while retaining more traditional, warm and welcoming hotel qualities. The designers chose to dress the hotel in shades of white with splashes of colours, more particularly red and gold, associated with ornamented tapestry as reminders of the Baroque style Italians crave for.

If you plan to spend the day wandering around Parma, this hotel is for you! It is close to the main shopping streets, the cathedral, the ducal park and the famous Piazza Garibaldi. As a little extra to start the day on a good foot, the Savoy Hotel provides excellent breakfast, comprised of traditional croissants, omelettes and pastries, as well as Parma ham and other regional specialities if you feel like it. As for the other meals, the hotel struck a deal with the wonderful Il Pianetino restaurant located just a few metres away. They serve large plates of cold cuts, exquisite milk-fed lamb ribs and the best meat in town. Everything with al dente greens.

content.title: Museo Civico Medievale, take a plunge into history!

introduction.small: Located in the Ghisilardi Fava Palazzo, one of the most sumptuous buildings of Bologna, the museum is a testimony of life in the Middle-Ages, the city's golden age.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Museo Civico Medievale, take a plunge into history!

paragraphs.text:
Opened in 1985 Via Manzoni, away from the tumultuous life of the city centre﻿, the Medieval Civic Museum is part of an ensemble of museums called "Arte Antica" (consisting in City art collections, the Davia Bargellini Museum and the Vittorio Zironi Fabric and Tapestry Museum). It is located at the heart of the Ghisilardi Fava Palazzo, a gem of Renaissance architecture that was built at the very end of the 15th century.

Inside, the collections are exceptional and you can discover crafted tools from the 7th, 8th and 9th centuries, marble and ivory sculptures, ornamented parchments, an impressive collection of armours and weapons - mostly from the 16th century, and ancient Murano glass items.

As part of the city academic tradition, the Medieval Civic Museum shelters several remarkable sculpted tombs that portray teaching scholars. The masterpiece of the museum's collection is undoubtedly the Boniface VIII bronze statue, crafted in 1301 by Manno Bandini da Siena.

Museo Civico Medievale

content.title: Oltre., gastronomy chic in Bologna

introduction.small: Trendy restaurant in Bologna, Oltre. gives a new stylish turn to Bolognese cuisine with modernised Italian specialities.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Oltre., gastronomy chic in Bologna

paragraphs.text:
The menu is simple and stripped down yet demanding. It was conceived over months by chef Daniele Bendanti, who worked in several starred restaurant across Italy. At Oltre. (with a period), food is undeniably Bolognese, "so as not to forget its roots", whilst "maintaining flavours and simplicity". Traditional cuisine then, yet different from the others, as a chic alternative based on high quality products.

Oltre. is the result of a joint effort between three men: Daniele Bendanti in the kitchen, Lorenzo Giacomo Costa for service and Jacopo Pozzati for the design of the place, warm and contemporary, dressed with trendy furniture. On the façade of the building, you can try and decipher the thousands of stickers up the walls.

As for the cooking, you should not miss the tagliatelle al ragù, the genuine Bolognese sauce. The chef signature dish brings together pigeon, cauliflower and cherries! As a nice bonus, Oltre. developed its own beers and liquors, all homemade.

content.title: Motor Valley fast Italian engines

introduction.small: Italian cars and motorcycles remain first-rate and the Motor Valley track reveals the sporting spirit alive in the region.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Motor Valley fast Italian engines

paragraphs.text:
You can almost hear the sound of engines inside the Ducati Museum of Bologna. Inaugurated in 1998, it shelters the motorcycle models that made the prestigious brand history and offers some hindsight into its creation process, from the assembly line to future projects still on paper.

These past years, automobile museums have spring up like mushrooms in the region. Less than one hour from Bologna, the Enzo Ferrari Museum of Modena is located in the house where the founder of the brand was born. Over 5,000 sqm, it exhibits an eclectic collection of cars, documents and posters that unveils the story of Ferrari. A few kilometres from there in the town of Maranello - famous for its racetrack, stands another Ferrari museum, housing real Formula 1 driving simulator.

There are other museums in the vicinity, notably the Lamborghini one in Sant'Agata Bolognese, in between Modena and Bologna.

content.title: Zerocinquantello, street food made in Bologna

introduction.small: Hidden in a small paved shopping street between greengrocers, butcher shops and cafés, Zerocinquantello offers a wealth of Bolognese cuisine, on the run.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Zerocinquantello, street food made in Bologna

paragraphs.text:
The address belongs to a small network of three restaurants all specialised in typical products from Emilia-Romagna. The newcomer of the Zerocinquantello chain brings the 051 (“Zerocinquantino”, name of the flagship restaurant located right across) concept to the canteen version. Street food is the backbone of the restaurant, which is typical cuisine you can either eat in or take away. Zerocinquantello works like a small bar where you can order cold cuts or pasta, with a glass of Italian wine of course.
If you want to have brunch with some friends, you can either choose the inner dining room or the terrace, but prepare your outing in advance for the place is crowded. For lunch between two museum visits, the best option is to take away. On the menu, you have a choice of mortadella ham, tortellini al ragù, lasagne but also tigelle, small rolls usually accompanied with ham, and polpettine, meatballs Italians are fond of.

content.title: The charms of the historical centre

introduction.small: Whether by foot or on a bike, a visit of the historical centre is mandatory. The city is riddled with medieval and Renaissance monuments, which constitute a true architectural and historical feast.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The charms of the historical centre

paragraphs.text:
The old city is restricted to pedestrians and revolves around the Piazza Maggiore, a huge square that goes back to the Middle-Ages and was reconfigured as centuries went by. It is riddled with historical monuments and buildings, such as the infamous Bologna archways that stretch on almost 40 km. On the Piazza itself, the Palazzo d'Accursio shelters the current city hall and a museum.

Symbols of the Bologna, the Asinelli and Garisenda towers were built in the 11th and 12th centuries by powerful families to avoid wars. They are both leaning and the tallest in the city. Today, only 20 of these towers remain, but in the past, they were close to a hundred. Nearby, the Fountain of Neptune which was built out of bronze and marble in 1560 is the symbol of the papal power. Spread across the heart of the city, many other monuments are just waiting for you to discover them, like the Palazzo Podesta or the Palazzo Re Enzo. And remember, you can always ask your way around when in Bologna!

https://www.bolognawelcome.com/en/

content.title: The Metropolitan, trendy hotel

introduction.small: Unlike many hotels in Bologna, The Metropolitan chose the path of designer decoration. Welcome to a temple of elegance and simplicity.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Metropolitan, trendy hotel

paragraphs.text:
The minimalist decoration of the Metropolitan Hotel riffs on designer trends and makes for a change within the Baroque city. The hotel is fully anchored in the 21st century with a very urban style. The decoration of the 45 rooms offers neutral tones - white and beige predominantly, uplifted by small traces of vivid colours and eastern touches. There is a clear will to give the place a timeless feel, with refined lines and ultramodern furniture.

If you crave for rare and unusual areas within the city, the considerate hotel concierge will provide you with the addresses of genuine Italian restaurants. Located near the historical centre, the Metropolitan Hotel is also very close to the Piazza Maggiore and the major museums in Bologna. It is an ideal starting point to discover the city. And if you would rather rent an apartment, the hotel also offers one and two-bedroom accommodations, as well as small studios.

Hotel Metropolitan

content.title: Art Hotel Commercianti: a window onto San Petronio

introduction.small: This charming boutique hotel located in the heart of the historical centre is a reflection of Bologna's soul, between past and future.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Art Hotel Commercianti: a window onto San Petronio

paragraphs.text:
Closely related to the city history, the hotel never stopped changing. Two steps away from the Piazza Maggiore, the Art Hotel Commercianti offers a stunning view onto the San Petronio basilica and its wonderful gothic stained-glass windows. Completely unusual, it integrates elements of middle-aged decorum to its current architecture.

In the bedrooms, you will therefore be able to admire the vaulted ceilings and exposed beams of the original building. It is also worth mentioning the frescoes painted on the walls according to ancestral techniques. Fabrics, furniture and interior design have been chosen in accordance with this architecture, which gives the hotel a warm and romantic atmosphere. From the terrace of certain bedrooms, you will feel like you could almost touch the basilica's brick walls. And if you are lucky, you could even listen to the organ being played.

The offer of Art Hotel Commercianti includes free breakfast, wireless connection in almost all premises and a bicycle loan service. For some unique culinary experiences, it will also be possible to book a table at a typical restaurant in the centre of Bologna.

content.title: Diana, retro cuisine

introduction.small: In typical Bolognese fashion, the restaurant offers tortellini, lasagna, tagliatelle and other traditional regional dishes. This is a must-go-to.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Diana, retro cuisine

paragraphs.text:
If you visit the city for the first time, take the opportunity to stroll down Via Volturno and cross the threshold at Diana's, the temple of traditional Bolognese cuisine. The slightly vintage decor will instantly take you to 1909 Italia, when the place first opened.

Diana makes no fuss with the decoration: white tablecloths, a few frames upon the walls, a lovely vintage clock hanging in the middle of the dining room and a subtly ornamented ceiling.

Food and service are on par. Waiters wear suits (with ties or bowties, it depends) and they carve or slice meat and fish in front of you, proudly exhibiting their craft. The menu is extremely varied, as it offers tender roasted meat, penny buns, parmesan and truffles salad, essential pasta dishes, as well as seafood. Of course, the wine list is just as complete. Thankfully, the sommelier will be there to guide you pick a wine that matches your dish.

Ristorante Diana

content.title: Enjoying strolls in Parma

introduction.small: Palaces built during the Renaissance, historical streets, lively cultural and artistic scene... If perfection had a name, it would be Parma.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Enjoying strolls in Parma

paragraphs.text:
Only an hour from Bologna by car, the wondrous city of Parma, of which Etruscan origins go back to Antiquity, is well worth the trip. You will love strolling along the charming narrow streets and wandering around for a whole sunny afternoon on the Piazza Garibaldi. Take some time to admire the Palazzo Ducale de Colorno, and make sure you buy tickets to see an opera by Verdi.

On the food stalls around the city, prosciutto di Parma and parmigiano Reggiano reign supreme. They both are the reflection of unique craft and are Protected Designations of Origin. Informed travellers will tell you that even in local supermarkets, these products are of far better quality than the ones destined for exportation. So do not hesitate, take advantage!

As an intense cultural centre, the House of Farnese maintained a bright artistic output unique in Europe throughout the Renaissance. Ever since that time, Parma has housed architectural marvels like the Duomo, the cathedral, the Farnese theatre, the small palaces that circle the Piazza Garibaldi, and most recently the Niccolò Paganini auditorium designed by Renzo Piano.

Parma Tourist Office
Piazza Garibaldi 1
43121 Parma

+39 052 121 8889

https://www.parmawelcome.it/en/

content.title: Al Capello Rosso pays tribute to multiple art forms

introduction.small: Inhabitants of Bologna consider Al Capello Rosso to be the oldest hotel in town. And yet, it is moved by only one principle: reinvention.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Al Capello Rosso pays tribute to multiple art forms

paragraphs.text:
You barely crossed the threshold and the sign says it already: Albergo in Bologna dal 1375 (hotel in Bologna since 1375). This boutique hotel offers 33 rooms and five small apartments, and built its reputation on excellent skills and service, refined for 600 years.

If you spend a few minutes with the owners, you will understand that they love their city deeply. Their constant and considerate attentions, as well as a perfectionist will to renew themselves, are bound to please you. Very much involved in the city's cultural life, they sponsor the comic book BilBOlbul International Festival almost every year. Hence why five of the bedrooms have been decorated with this theme in mind. As for the others, they put forward cinema, drawing, music, fashion and literature... Arts in general.

Open for lunch and dinner, the Osteria del Cappello restaurant offers local and national specialities: meat platters and cold cuts, tortellini and tagliatelle with Bolognese ragù sauce, tigelle and crescentine. As you can well imagine, good taste and beauty are everywhere to be found at Capello Rosso.

content.title: Discover the National Pinacotheca

introduction.small: The Pinacotheca is the largest museum in Emilia-Romagna. It offers visitors a retrospective of Italian art, especially from the Bologna region from the 13th to the 18th century.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Discover the National Pinacotheca

paragraphs.text:
There is no shortage of Italian creative geniuses: Leonardo da Vinci, Michelangelo, Raphael and many others. A heritage that makes the whole country proud. Whether in painting or sculpture, the different Italian schools have definitely put their stamp on art history. Bologna's Pinacoteca Nazionale

pays tribute to the numerous artists of the region with a particularly comprehensive collection of works. Two steps away from the university, it offers more than 30 exhibition areas, ordinated by school and era.

The collection has been considerably enriched over the years thanks to various donations. You will therefore be able to admire works by the Carracci brothers Agostino and Annibale, as well as their cousin Lodovico, the three of them Bolognese painters who will later influence Nicolas Poussin. Artists of the Baroque movement like Domenichino and Guercino are also represented.

Besides the permanent collection and the various temporary exhibitions held each year, the museum houses the Academy of Fine Arts and offers playful activities that will delight your little ones.

content.title: Cultural heritage of Bologna University

introduction.small: Visit the university and travel through time, from the Middle-Ages to the Renaissance, amongst so many other periods.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Cultural heritage of Bologna University

paragraphs.text:
Bologna is the first western university. As soon as 1088, students from all over the world gathered to learn from the most influential teachers of the time, who would teach grammar, rhetoric, oriental studies, mathematics and medicine. Besides some great teachers, History now remembers above all things the names of various students who became figureheads in literature, arts and science, like Petrach, Copernicus, Dürer, Paracelsus, Pico della Mirandola, and Tasso.

A true talents factory, the University of Bologna located during the 16th century at the heart of the Archiginnasio Palace. The building has now become a huge library that shelters thousands of old texts and manuscripts. It is also possible to discover the coats of arms of the richest students' families that have been linked to the establishment. Do not miss the visit of the anatomical theatre, in which the first studies on the human body were performed in Europe, thus allowing for major scientific progress.

The rooms are modern and cosy, directly inspired by the colours one finds in local natural elements to create a sense of absolute happiness.

Extend your quest for pleasure by enjoying a 360° vista of Rimini on the eighth floor. And then let the peace and quiet of the various well-being spaces sink in. As for the daylight bar, it offers aperitif and cocktail tastings in the midst of two walled gardens within the hotel. So many options to prolong that cocooning experience, just before ending the day with a resting walk on the seafront.

content.title: Bologna's film library: as archives go by

introduction.small: For film lovers, the film library is a true goldmine with screenings of rare movies and documentaries, as well as a sophisticated and demanding programming.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Bologna's film library: as archives go by

paragraphs.text:
Born 50 years ago under the then-mayor's patronage, this Bolognese cultural hotspot pays tribute to the 7th art in all shapes and forms. You can browse this impressive film collection of worldwide heritage, where thousands of film reels are treasured. From silent cinema greats like Chaplin to independent movies and documentaries, they are all being restored by the Cineteca di Bologna.

Digital transition now being a necessity to keep those gems alive, each year, thousands of works are being scanned within these walls and then screened in the two integrated theatres on site. The Scorsese screening room is devoted to old classics and unknown masterpieces while the Mastroianni one is selected for independent foreign subtitled movies. Furthermore, the Cineteca programs several events along the year. Just ask for the program!
